section.name: Overview
section.p:
This reference is split up into the following sections:
Language Elements
Literals
Functions
Operators
Access
Control Statements
For more technical information about the JEXL Grammar, you can find the JavaCC grammar for JEXL here: Parser.jjt

tr.td: Specified using ## or //and extend to the end of line, e.g. ## This is a comment Also specified using //, e.g. // This is a comment Multiple lines comments are specified using /*...*/, e.g. /* This is a multi-line comment */

Must start with a-z, A-Z, _ or $. Can then be followed by 0-9, a-z, A-Z, _ or $. e.g.
Valid: var1,_a99,$1
Invalid: 9v,!a99,1$
N.B. the following keywords are reserved, and cannot be used as an identifier or the property name when using the dot operator: or and eq ne lt gt le ge in div mod not this null true false instanceof new var final do while break continue remove function return try catch finally throw synchronized switch case default byte short int long char boolean float double For example, the following is invalid: my.new.dotted.var1 // invalid ('new' is keyword) In such cases, quoted identifiers or the [ ] operator can be used, for example: my.'new'.dotted.var1 my['new'].dotted.var1

td.p: A script in JEXL is made up of zero or more statements, optionally enclosed in a function definition block. One or more pragmas can be specified at the beginning of the script.
Scripts can be read from a String, File or URL.
Scripts can be created with named parameters which allow a later evaluation to be performed with arguments.
By default scripts return the value of the last evaluated statement.
Using the return keyword, a script will return the expression that follows (or null).

tr.td:
Declares a pragma, a method to communicate information from a script to its execution environment, e.g. #pragma execution.option 42 will declare a pragma named execution.option with a value of 42.
Pragma keys can be identifiers or antish names, pragma values can be literals (boolean, integer, real, string, null, NaN) and antish names

A statement can be the empty statement, the semicolon (;), block, control statement, variable declaration, multiple assignment, or an expression. Statements are optionally terminated with a semicolon. A single statement or a statement block can be annotated.

A block is simply multiple statements inside curly braces ({, }).
The labeled syntax is also supported: foo : {...} Where the label foo can be used in the inner break statements.

Can be specified outside of the script to create the evaluation context. Contextual variables is of lower precedence in resolution over local variables.
Contextual variable names are case-sensitive, e.g. var1 and Var1 are different variables.
JEXL supports ant-style contextual variables, the following is a valid variable name: my.dotted.var
An expression can be the literal, variable, assignment, access operator, iterator operator, stream operator, function definition, function call, method call or an evaluation operator.
Assigns the value of a variable (my.var = 'a value') using a JexlContext as initial resolver. Both beans and ant-ish variables assignment are supported.

Assigns the values to the multiple variables ((x,y) = [4,2]). Assignment can be combined with local variable declaration using the var keyword, e.g. var (x,y) = [4,2] will assign 4 and 2 to the variables x and y respectively. The syntax can be used for arrays as well as lists and sets, as well as other expressions that return either of these.
If the list of variables assigned to has more variables than values, excess ones are filled with null values. If the list of variables has less variables than values, the extra values are ignored.
Multiple assignment can also be used as destructuring assignment when applied to maps and beans, e.g. var (city,street) = {"city":"NY","street":"5th avenue"} will assign NY and 5th avenue to the variables city and street respectively. The variable names should match those of bean properties, or map keys, e.g. var (city) = foo and var city = foo.city are equivalent.

Calling a function follows the usual convention, e.g. fun(17, 25) will call the fun function with arguments 17 and 25
Argument comprehentions syntax can also be used to pass variable number of arguments based on other iterable objects, like collections and arrays, e.g. fun(...[17, 25]) will call the fun function with arguments 17 and 25

Calls a method of an object, e.g. "hello world".hashCode() will call the hashCode method of the "hello world" String.
In case of multiple arguments and overloading, JEXL will make the best effort to find the most appropriate non ambiguous method to call.

td.p: Allows to evaluate a property of an object, a value of the collection or an array by using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. foo.bar will access the bar property of the foo Object. arr1[0] will access the first element of the of the arr1 array.
Multidimensional array access operator form arr1[x,y] can be used instead of sequential arr1[x][y] form

The safe-access operator foo?.bar shortcuts any null or non-existent references along the navigation path, allowing a safe-navigation free of errors. In the previous expression, if 'foo' is null, the whole expression will evaluate as null. This is an efficient shortcut to defensive expressions such as x?.y?.z that would otherwise be expressed as x? (x.y? (x.y.z ?: null) :null) : null.

Properties can also be quoted as in foo.'b a r' and can be dynamic back-quoted interpolation strings as in cal.`${dd.year}-${dd.month}-${dd.day}`. These syntaxes are mixable with safe-access as in foo.'b a r'?.quux or foo?.`${bar}`.quux.
Access operators can be overloaded in JexlArithmetic, so that the operator behaviour will differ depending on the type of the operator arguments

tr.td:
Returns an iterator of iterable object, e.g. ...[1,2,3] will return an iterator producing items of the corresponding array.
Iterator can also be specified in a form of generator function e.g. ...(initValue : x -> {x < 10 ? x + 2 : null}). Generator iterator terminates only when the generator function returns null; If the initValue is null, then the initally empty iterator will be created.
The generator function can also take two arguments (index, value) -> {index < 10 ? value + 2 : null} with the first argument index being the zero based index of the next generated element of the sequence, and the second value is the previously generated element.

Performs computational, logical or comparative action between one, two or three arguments whose values are expressions, e.g. 40 + 2 will call the add operator between two integer literals.
All operators, except when stated otherwise, can be overloaded in JexlArithmetic, so that the action taken will differ depending on the type of the operator arguments

td.p: Stream operators allows to perform transformations of iterable objects into iterators or values. Stream operator can be a projection operator, selection operator or reduction operator

Projection operator creates an iterator that produces values specified in the projection. Projection operator can be either an array projection operator a.[foo,bar] or a key-value projection operator a.{foo:bar}. The projection dimensions can be defined either as the properties of the object, a.[foo] or as lambda expressions a.[x - > {x.foo}].
Selection operator creates an iterator that produces only the values that satisfy the specified selection condition a.(x - > {x.foo.length() > 10})
Reduction operator evaluates a scalar value from iterable object a.$(0 : (x,y) - > {x+y})

tr.td: 1 or more digits from 0 to 9, eg 42.
1 or more digits from 0 to 9, followed by a decimal point and then one or more digits from 0 to 9, optionally followed by f or F, eg 42.0 or 42.0f.
1 or more digits from 0 to 9 suffixed with l or L , eg 42l.
1 or more digits from 0 to 9, followed by a decimal point and then one or more digits from 0 to 9 suffixed with d or D , eg 42.0d. A special literal NaN can be used to denote Double.NaN constant
1 or more digits from 0 to 9 suffixed with h or H (for Huge ala OGNL, "does not interfere with hexa-decimal digits"), eg 42h.
1 or more digits from 0 to 9, followed by a decimal point and then one or more digits from 0 to 9 suffixed with b or B) , eg 42.0b.
Natural literals - octal and hex support

Natural numbers (i.e. Integer, Long, BigInteger) can also be expressed as octal or hexadecimal using the same format as Java. i.e. prefix the number with 0 for octal, and prefix with 0x or 0X for hexadecimal. For example 010 or 0x10.

Real numbers (i.e. Float, Double, BigDecimal) can also be expressed using standard Java exponent notation. i.e. suffix the number with e or E followed by the sign + or - followed by one or more decimal digits. For example 42.0E-1D or 42.0E+3B.

Can start and end with either ' or " delimiters, e.g. "Hello world" and 'Hello world' are equivalent.
The escape character is \ (backslash); it only escapes the string delimiter

Start and end with ` delimiter - back-quote -, e.g. `Hello world`
The escape character is \ (backslash); it only escapes the string delimiter. These format literals can span multiple lines and allow Unified JEXL expressions (JSTL like expressions) to be interpolated. If a variable user valued JEXLis present in the environment - whether as a local or global variable -, the format `Hello ${user}` will evaluate as Hello JEXL.

Start with ~/ and ends with / delimiters, e.g. ~/ABC.*/
The escape character is \ (backslash); it only escapes the string delimiter \ (slash)
The literals true and false can be used, e.g. val1 == true
The literal this allows to explicitly access contextual variables in situations when they are covered by local variables or have non-standard names, e.g. this.val1 this["var"]
The null value is represented as in java using the literal null, e.g. val1 == null

A [ followed by zero or more expressions separated by , and ending with ], e.g. [ 1, 2, "three" ]
This syntax creates an Object[].
Empty array literal can be specified as [] with result of creating Object[]
Array comprehentions syntax can also be used to construct arrays based on other iterable objects, like collections and arrays, e.g.[1, 2, 3, ...[4, 5, 6]]
JEXL will attempt to strongly type the array; if all entries are of the same class or if all entries are Number instance, the array literal will be an MyClass[] in the former case, a Number[] in the latter case.
Furthermore, if all entries in the array literal are of the same class and that class has an equivalent primitive type, the array returned will be a primitive array. e.g. [1, 2, 3] will be interpreted as int[].

A [ followed by zero or more expressions separated by , and ending with ,...], e.g. [ 1, 2, "three",...]
This syntax creates an ArrayList<Object>.
Empty list literal can be specified as [...]
List comprehentions syntax can also be used to construct lists based on other iterable objects, like collections and arrays, e.g.[1, 2, 3, ...[4, 5, 6],...]

A #[ followed by zero or more expressions separated by , and ending with ], e.g. #[ 1, 2, "three"]
This syntax creates an immutable List<Object>.
Empty immutable list literal can be specified as #[]
List comprehentions can also be used like in conventional List literal syntax

A value followed by .. and ending with other value, e.g. 1 .. 42
This syntax creates a 'range' object in the form of a java iterable which can be used in for statement, e.g. for (i : 1..42) a = a + b[i]

Evaluates whether an expression if 'empty'. This is true when the argument is:
null
An instance of class C and the derived JexlArithmetic overloads a method 'public boolean empty(C arg)' that returns true when the argument is considered empty
An empty string
An array of length zero
A collection of size zero
An empty map
An iterator which 'hasNext()' method returns false
Defining a method 'public boolean isEmpty()' that returns true when the instance is considered empty
This is false in other cases (besides errors). empty(arg)

Evaluates the 'size' of an expression. This returns:
0 if the argument is null
The result of calling a method from a derived JexlArithmetic overload 'public int size(C arg)', C being the class of the argument
Length of an array
Length of a string
Size of a Collection
Size of a Map
The result of calling a method 'public int size()' defined by the argument class
This returns 0 in other cases (besides errors). size("Hello") returns 5.

Creates a new instance using a fully-qualified class name or Class: new("java.lang.Double", 10) returns 10.0.
Note that the first argument of new can be a variable or any expression evaluating as a String or Class; the rest of the arguments are used as arguments to the constructor for the class considered.
In case of multiple constructors, JEXL will make the best effort to find the most appropriate non ambiguous constructor to call.

Top level function is a function which can be invoked without specifying a namespace.
Top level function can be defined by the function definition method inside the script
A JexlContext can define methods which can be invoked as top level functions. This can allow expressions like: string(23.0)
Another way to define top level function is to register to JexlEngine objects or classes with null namespace.
A JexlEngine can register objects or classes used as function namespaces. This can allow expressions like: math:cosinus(23.0)

td.p: The usual && operator can be used as well as the word and, e.g. cond1 and cond2 and cond1 && cond2 are equivalent.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded
The usual || operator can be used as well as the word or, e.g. cond1 or cond2 and cond1 || cond2 are equivalent.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded
The usual ! operator can be used as well as the word not, e.g. !cond1 and not cond1 are equivalent.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded

tr.td: The usual & operator is used, e.g. 33 & 4, 0010 0001 & 0000 0100 = 0.
The usual ~ operator is used, e.g. ~33, ~0010 0001 = 1101 1110 = -34.

The usual ternary conditional operator condition ? if_true : if_false operator can be used as well as the abbreviation value ? if_true which returns the if_true if its evaluation is defined, non-null and non-false, e.g. val1 ? val2 : null and val1 ? val2 are equivalent.
NOTE: The condition will evaluate to false when it refers to an undefined variable or null for all JexlEngine flag combinations. This allows explicit syntactic leniency and treats the condition 'if undefined or null or false' the same way in all cases.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded

The binary conditional operator value ?: if_false returns the value if its evaluation is defined, non-null and non-false, e.g. val1 ?: val2 and val1 ? val1 : val2 are equivalent.
NOTE: The condition will evaluate to false when it refers to an undefined variable or null for all JexlEngine flag combinations. This allows explicit syntactic leniency and treats the condition 'if undefined or null or false' the same way in all cases.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded

The null coalescing operator returns the result of its first operand if it is defined and is not null.
When xandyare null or undefined, x ?? 'unknown or null x' evaluates as 'unknown or null x' y ?? "default" evaluates as "default".
When var x = 42 and var y = "forty-two",x??"other" evaluates as 42 and y??"other" evaluates as "forty-two".
NOTE: this operator does not behave like the ternary conditional since it does not coerce the first argument to a boolean to evaluate the condition. When var x = false and var y = 0,x??true evaluates as false and y??1 evaluates as 0.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded

The usual == operator can be used as well as the abbreviation eq. For example val1 == val2 and val1 eq val2 are equivalent.
null is only ever equal to null, that is if you compare null to any non-null value, the result is false.
Equality uses the java equals method
The usual != operator can be used as well as the abbreviation ne. For example val1 != val2 and val1 ne val2 are equivalent.

The syntactically Perl inspired =~ operator can be used to check that a string matches a regular expression (expressed either a Java String or a java.util.regex.Pattern). For example "abcdef" =~ "abc.* returns true. It also checks whether any collection, set or map (on keys) contains a value or not; in that case, it behaves as an "in" operator. Note that arrays and user classes exposing a public 'contains' method will allow their instances to behave as right-hand side operands of this operator. "a" =~ ["a","b","c","d","e",f"] returns true.

The syntactically Perl inspired !~ operator can be used to check that a string does not match a regular expression (expressed either a Java String or a java.util.regex.Pattern). For example "abcdef" !~ "abc.* returns false. It also checks whether any collection, set or map (on keys) does not contain a value; in that case, it behaves as "not in" operator. Note that arrays and user classes exposing a public 'contains' method will allow their instances to behave as right-hand side operands of this operator. "a" !~ ["a","b","c","d","e",f"] returns true.

The === operator can be used to test that left and right arguments are the same object. For example val1 === val2.
null is considered to be identical only to null, that is if you compare null to any non-null value, the result is false.
Identity differs from equality that it does not use the java equals method
Note that this operator can not be overloaded

The !== operator can be used to test that left and right arguments are different objects. For example val1 !== val2. This is the reverse of the identity operator.
Note that this operator can not be overloaded
The usual < operator can be used as well as the abbreviation lt. For example val1 < val2 and val1 lt val2 are equivalent.
The usual <= operator can be used as well as the abbreviation le. For example val1 <= val2 and val1 le val2 are equivalent.
The usual > operator can be used as well as the abbreviation gt. For example val1 > val2 and val1 gt val2 are equivalent.
The usual >= operator can be used as well as the abbreviation ge. For example val1 >= val2 and val1 ge val2 are equivalent.

The =^ operator is a short-hand for the 'startsWith' method. For example, "abcdef" =^ "abc" returns true. Note that through duck-typing, user classes exposing a public 'startsWith' method will allow their instances to behave as left-hand side operands of this operator.
This is the negation of the 'starts with' operator. a !^ "abc" is equivalent to !(a =^ "abc")

The =$ operator is a short-hand for the 'endsWith' method. For example, "abcdef" =$ "def" returns true. Note that through duck-typing, user classes exposing an 'endsWith' method will allow their instances to behave as left-hand side operands of this operator.
This is the negation of the 'ends with' operator. a !$ "abc" is equivalent to !(a =$ "abc")

The 'instanceof' operator is used to test whether the object is an instance of the specified type (class or subclass or interface). For example "abc" instanceof String returns true. The type name can be either a java primitive type name, a simple name, or a fully qualified name, e.g. "abc" instanceof String and "abc" instanceof java.lang.String are equivalent. A simple class name can be used in the following cases:
for the classes in package java.lang.*
for the classes in package java.util.*
for the classes in package java.io.*
for the classes in package java.net.*
for classes without packages
for java.math.BigDecimal and java.math.BigInteger classes
The array syntax is also supported, e.g. ["abc", "def"] instanceof String[], or [1,2,3] instanceof int[].
Note that this operator can not be overloaded
The 'cast' operator is used to the conversion of one data type to another. For example (char)42 returns '*'. The type name to cast the value to can be any java primitive type name.

Creates a new instance using a class name: new Double(10) returns 10.0. The type name can be either a simple name, or a fully qualified name, e.g. new String("abc") and new java.lang.String("abc") are equivalent. A simple class name can be used in the same cases as specified for the instanceof operator.
In case of multiple constructors, JEXL will make the best effort to find the most appropriate non ambiguous constructor to call.
The array syntax is also supported, e.g. new String[5], or new int[5][7]
The array initialization syntax is also supported for single-dimension arrays, e.g. new String[] {'abc','def'}
Note that this operator can not be overloaded
The usual binary signed left shift << operator is used. For example val1 << 2
The usual binary signed right shift >> operator is used. For example val1 >> 2
The usual binary unsigned right shift >>>> operator is used. For example val1 >>> 2
The usual + operator is used. For example val1 + val2
The usual - operator is used. For example val1 - val2
The usual * operator is used. For example val1 * val2
The usual / operator is used, or one can use the div operator. For example val1 / val2 or val1 div val2
The % operator is used. An alternative is the mod operator. For example 5 mod 2 gives 1 and is equivalent to 5 % 2

Some operators exist in side-effect forms. Their default behavior is to execute the operator and assign the left-hand side with the result. For instance a += 2 is equivalent to a = a + 2 The list of operators is:
+=
-=
*=
/=
%=
&=
|=
^=
<<=
>>=
>>>=

The ++ operator is used. The default behavior is to increment value and assign the operand with the result. For instance ++a is equivalent to a = a + 1 operator.
The postfix form is also supported: a++

The -- operator is used. The default behavior is to decrement value and assign the operand with the result. For instance --a is equivalent to a = a - 1 operator.
The postfix form is also supported: a--
The unary - operator is used. For example -12
The unary + operator is used. For example +12
The unary & operator is used to get a pointer of a variable or a property. e.g. &a Pointer values can be dereferenced via dereference operator, e.g. var x = 1; var y = &x; *y = 2

The unary * operator is used. e.g. *a Note that through duck-typing, user classes exposing a get() method will allow their instances to behave as an operand of this operator.
The assignment to a dereferenced object is also supported: *a = 10, any user classes exposing a set(Object) method will allow their instances to accept such assignments.
The unary empty operator behaves exactly as the corresponding function empty(). For example empty arg and empty(arg) are equivalent
The unary size operator behaves exactly as the corresponding function size(). For example size [1,2,3] and size([1,2,3]) are equivalent
Array elements may be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. arr1[0] and arr1.0 are equivalent
List elements may be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. list[0] and list.0 are equivalent

Map elements are accessed using square brackets, e.g. map[0]; map['name']; map[var]; Note that map['7'] and map[7] refer to different elements. Map elements with a numeric key may also be accessed using a dotted numeral, e.g. map[0] and map.0 are equivalent.
Note that map.1 and map.01 refer to different elements, while map.1 and map[01] are equivalent.

Properties of JavaBean objects that define appropriate getter methods can be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. foo['bar'] and foo.bar are equivalent. The appropriate Foo.getBar() method will be called.
Note that both foo.Bar and foo.bar can be used

Indexed properties of JavaBean objects that define appropriate getter methods can be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. x.attribute['name'] and x.attribute.name are equivalent. The appropriate Foo.getAttribute(String index) method will be called
Public fields of java objects can be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. foo['bar'] and foo.bar are equivalent.

Properties of Java classes that define public Object get(String name) method can be accessed using either square brackets or a dotted numeral, e.g. foo['bar'] and foo.bar are equivalent. The appropriate Foo.get(String index) method will be called with the argument of "bar" String

An array projection operator a.[foo,bar] can define one or more projection dimensions. In case of only one defined dimension a.[foo], the projection operator creates an iterator that produces a single value. In case of more than one defined dimension a.[foo,bar,quux], the projection operator creates an iterator that produces an array of the corresponding values.
A key-value projection operator a.{foo:bar} creates an iterator that produces Map.Entry object with a key and a value.

A selection operator a.(x -> {x.length() > 10}) creates an iterator that produces only the objects that satisfy the specified condition. In its basic form the function takes one argument which is the next element of the iterable object. In extended form the function can take two arguments (index,value) -> {index < 10} with the first argument index being the zero based index of the next element of the iterable object, and the second value is the next element itself.

A reduction operator a.@(defaultValue : (result,value) -> {result + value}) evaluates the specified function to produce a value from series of values returned by an iterable object. If the iterable object contains no data, the defaultValue will be returned, otherwise the function (result,value) -> {result + value} will be called for each value returned by the iterable object. In its basic form the function takes two arguments, with the first argument result being a partial reduction operator result, and the second argument value being the next element of the iterable object. The function can also take only one argument result -> {result + 1}, or take no arguments at all() -> {nextid()}. In extended form the function can take three arguments (result,index,value) -> {result + value} with additional argument index being the zero based index of the next element of the iterable object.
Note that the default value of the reduction operator can be omitted a.@((result,value) -> {result + value}), in that case the default value will be null

td.p: Note that the loop variable i is accessible after loop evaluation
Note that the loop variable item is accessible after loop evaluation
The JEXL 1.1 syntax using foreach(item in list) is now unsupported.

tr.td:
Within loops (do/while/for), allows to skip to the next iteration.
The labeled syntax is also supported: continue foo Where the label foo specifies the loop to which the operation should apply to.

Within 'for' loops, allows to remove current element from underlying iterator collection and skip to the next iteration.
The labeled syntax is also supported: remove foo Where the label foo specifies the loop to which the operation should apply to.

Allows to break from a statement (do/while/for/switch/block) unconditionally.
The labeled syntax is also supported: break foo Where the label foo specifies the statement to which the operation should apply to.
Note that the unlabelled break statement can not be applied to an unlabelled block

Breaks current script/function execution and returns the value of the specified expression, e.g. return 42 If the returned value is not specified, the null will be returned, e.g.
return;

Throws an exception with the specified text message, e.g. throw "Something wrong here"
If the specified argument is the instance of the Throwable class, the provided exception will be rethrown

An assert is used to declare an expected boolean condition in a script, e.g. assert x == 0 or assert x == 0 : "Something wrong here" If the script is evaluated with assertions enabled, then the condition is checked during evaluation. If the condition is false, the assertion error is thrown.
